posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone,

It’s my pleasure to introduce you to LaserCAN - the first product from Grapple Robotics. LaserCAN is an FRC-ready, CAN-enabled laser ranging sensor with a range of up to 4 metres (13ft) and a configurable field of view. LaserCAN is absolutely tiny, at only 25x25mm (~1x1in).

lasercan2 1024×1024 88.3 KB

lasercan2 1024×1024 88.3 KB

lasercan2 1024×1024 88.3 KB

The LaserCAN can service any number of use cases:

Detect the presence of gamepieces in your intake,

Determine the distance between your robot and the goal,

Detect other robots getting in your personal space,

Get an absolute measure of your elevator height without dealing with encoders,

… and many more!

Cut to the chase Jaci, where do I learn more / buy one? - right here! LaserCAN – Grapple Robotics

(Don’t forget code KICKOFF20 to get 20% off prior to kickoff!)

From the same people that bought you GradleRIO and Pathfinder comes libgrapplefrc, our easy-to-use vendor library for both Java and C++.

View the status of your sensor, and reconfigure its settings from the companion app, GrappleHook.

image 1024×363 58.7 KB

image 1024×363 58.7 KB

image 1024×363 58.7 KB

No more guessing what each setting does, GrappleHook’s got your back. Want to target a narrower field of view? Want to target something on the flanks of the sensor? Configure it in a user-friendly interface.

image 1024×686 63.2 KB

image 1024×686 63.2 KB

image 1024×686 63.2 KB

Want to use multiple LaserCANs? Daisy-Chain up to 8 of them! image 915×375 71 KB

image 915×375 71 KB

image 915×375 71 KB

Grapple is committed to being open-source, which is why we’ve released everything about the LaserCAN. From the FRC vendor library , to the firmware , and to the PCB design files - all are available TODAY. No subscriptions, no paywalls, no obfuscation - completely open for you to peek under the hood.

Our first batch of sensors are arriving in the next few days, where they’ll be programmed and tested and shipped straight to you! LaserCAN ships from Australia via AusPost Domestic/International Standard or Express. Order now to receive yours before or soon after kickoff (depending on your location and order date).

We’re working to get a US store open to ease the shipping burden, however this likely won’t be ready by kickoff. Instead, use code KICKOFF20 to get 20% off your order (prior to kickoff) to help ease the shipping cost.

Thanks so much!

- Jaci, Grapple Robotics

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
Anything dealing with light we’ve had bad luck with.

So pardon my ignorance, Would these be susceptible to halogen or direct sunlight?

Edit: i see that ur typing. But you seem to have already answered my question with the YouTube video.  Next time just say “watch the video, idiot.”

Any chance these will be distributed within the US by a domestic vendor?

Edit: JK I see you answer this as well.

Seems Thrifty @Ryan_Dognaux

posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked:
Good question! I can’t speak for halogens since I don’t have any to test with, but in a sunlit room these sensors appear to be ranging just fine if not directed at the sun or straight at a window (until occluded).

In direct sunlight, you will find some interference issues since they operate in the IR spectrum. This may reduce the range of the sensor, or cause erroneous detections. If not pointed directly at an IR source (like the sun) though, I’ve generally found them to be quite reliable. You can read more about this here , and the datasheet specifies some details about the conditions under which the sensor is tested and rated.

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked: Added to MKCAD.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Are the daisy-chain CAN pads connected such that you could put this inline in a CAN loop with other products? We struggled with robustly T-wiring another sensor that only had two CAN lines in.

posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked: As long as it’s legal in the FRC rule book, absolutely! The CAN is a direct pass-through, so you can chain it as long as you’d like. As long as you’re not daisy-chaining power to a non-LaserCAN device, it should work a treat

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
Jaci:

Daisy-Chain up to 8 of them!

Is the daisy chain limitation only for power? A robot can have more than 8 LaserCAN devices as long as they aren’t daisy-chained?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Jaci:

As long as you’re not daisy-chaining power to a non-LaserCAN device

Is the concern with that about current draw through the LaserCAN board?

posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked: Primarily, yes. The traces on-board the LaserCAN are only rated for approx 0.8A to be comfortable. With each sensor using 80mA as the typical maximum (although in practice it’s closer to 50-60mA as measured on my multimeter), that’s 0.64A for 8 LaserCANs. If you really wanted to, you could have as many LaserCANs on a robot as there are CAN IDs available as long as they are branching from separate power every 8 devices.

posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked: Primarily yes, see above

posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked:
While we’re on the topic of power, it’s worth noting that it’s highly recommended to power the LaserCAN from the RoboRIO through either the 5V or 6V rail (exposed on the DIO and PWM pins). The LaserCAN can be powered from the main robot power supply through a fused output on the PDP/PDH, but for better noise rejection and less power wastage, it’s recommended to use the pre-regulated supplies on-board the RoboRIO.

The reason being is that the LaserCAN uses a linear voltage regulator which is regulating down to 3.3V. In a linear regulator, the closer your input is to the target voltage, the less wasted power is used (which is dissipated as heat). We’ve run the LaserCAN for an extended period of time on 13V and haven’t seen any issues relating to heat transfer, but to keep your LaserCAN as cool as possible it’s recommended to power it from the RIO. This’ll increase its lifespan and also save you some (negligible) battery life if you are using multiple LaserCANs.

* Why did we use a linear regulator? Well, switch-mode supplies are too big to fit in this form-factor. Furthermore, they generally require extra filtering which we simply can’t put in this form-factor.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: No shipping to Israel?

posts.name: Jaci
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately it seems that shipping to Israel comes with some import restrictions for electronic devices: Israel International post guide - Australia Post

I can’t find any solid details about this online, but I’ll see if I can find more details over the next week and see if we can open up shipping to Israel.

posts.name: Commonaught
posts.cooked:
As a lidar enjoyer I love this. A few questions:

What frequency do they scan at.

If I have multiple of them can I get them to synchronize their scanning?

When it scans, does it return a single distance or 16x16 (so 256 total) distance measurement.

How small can the FOV be configured? I.e. does it only work as a range finder or can it return an accurate point cloud?

posts.name: Commonaught
posts.cooked: I found on the website where is says the frequency is 10-50 Hz. Is there any disadvantage to configuring it to 50 Hz (for example to do you get lower range or accuracy at the highest frequency)?

posts.name: Commonaught
posts.cooked: Thought of another question: of I want to do something fairly computationally intensive with the data, will there be a good way of getting the sensor readings to a coprosseor like an orange PI with little latency?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You could use a USB-CAN adapter on the coprocessor to pick up the CAN messages directly.  In fact, since these are sensors, you could run a completely independent CAN bus with only these sensors and the coprocessor on it…
